step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with acute pneumonia symptoms (fever, purulent cough, chest consolidation) and a mild neutrophilic leukocytosis with left shift. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, including in hospitalized patients. The CBC shows elevated neutrophils (72%) and bands (4%), consistent with a bacterial infection. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is unlikely due to chronic presentation. Haemophilus influenzae is more common in younger patients. Staphylococcus aureus typically causes more severe infections with higher WBC counts. The clinical picture aligns best with S. pneumoniae.
